revision.text:
{{pp-pc1}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Jimmy Pardo | image = Jimmy Pardo.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Jimmy Pardo performing at [[Maximum Fun#MaxFunCon|MaxFunCon]] 2009 in Lake Arrowhead, California | pseudonym = | birth_name = James Ronald Pardo, Jr. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1966|7|28}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]] | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up Comedy]], [[Television]], [[Film]], [[Podcast]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | genre = [[Observational comedy]], [[Crowd manipulation|crowd work]], [[insult comedy]] | subject = [[popular culture|pop culture]], [[American culture]] | spouse = Danielle Koenig | notable_work = ''[[Never Not Funny]]''
''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]''
''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' | signature = | children = 1 | website = [http://www.jimmypardo.com/ JimmyPardo.com] |active = 1988 â€“ present }} '''James Ronald Pardo, Jr.''' (born July 28, 1966) is an American [[Stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]], actor, and host of the long-running comedy [[podcast]] ''[[Never Not Funny]]''. From the show's inception and until mid-2015, he performed as the [[Conan O'Brien]] program [[Conan (talk show)|''Conan'']]'s [[warm-up comedian]] and cast member, after which he received a general development deal with O'Brien's production company. He last hosted the game show ''[[Race to Escape]]'' on the Science Channel. ==Early life== Pardo was born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], and spent his first 8 years living on the south side, eventually moving to the south suburbs of Chicago. He spent his grade school years living in [[Hometown, Illinois]]. In 1980, his family moved to [[Oak Forest, Illinois]] where he attended [[Oak Forest High School]]. In 1986, he moved to [[Pasadena, California]] to attend the [[American Academy of Dramatic Arts]]. He attended for one year, then returned to Chicago to pursue a career in stand-up comedy. ==Career== In late 1988, Pardo started performing at open microphones at various venues around Chicago, including "The Roxy", "The Last Laugh" and "The Comedy Cottage". The plethora of successful [[comedy clubs]] in the area at that time meant Pardo started earning money almost immediately, allowing him to quit his day job as a sales rep for [[MCA Records]].{{cite web |last=Israel |first=David K. |date=April 30, 2009 |url=http://www.mentalfloss.com/blogs/archives/25118 |title=Creatively Speaking: Jimmy Pardo |website=Mental Floss |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615073250/http://www.mentalfloss.com/blogs/archives/25118 |archivedate=June 15, 2011 |df= }} In addition to his comedy CDs ''Uno'', ''Pompous Clown'' and ''Sprezzatura'', in 2007 Pardo appeared on the comedy compilation CD ''[[Comedy Death-Ray (album)|Comedy Death-Ray]]''. Pardo hosted [[Game Show Network|GSN]]'s ''[[National Lampoon's Funny Money]]'' from June to October 2003, and later co-hosted [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]]'s ''Movies At Our House'' with Rachel Quaintance for 5 seasons. Pardo was the warm-up comedian for ''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]'' after being suggested by head writer Mike Sweeney.{{Cite web |url=http://www.nuvo.net/indianapolis/how-the-bob-and-tom-show-made-jimmy-pardo/Content?oid=4534638 |title=How the Bob & Tom Show Made Jimmy Pardo |last=Johnson |first=Seth |work=[[Nuvo (newspaper)|Nuvo]] |date=January 25, 2017}} He has returned as the opening act for ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'',{{cite web |url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/41201 |title=No Couch For Richter?? A Report From A TONIGHT SHOW WITH CONAN O'BRIEN Test Show!! |website=[[Ain't It Cool News]] |date=May 27, 2009}} and appeared in a recurring on-air sketch throughout the week of April 11, 2011.[http://video.teamcoco.com/video/conan.jsp?oid=248567&eref=sharethisUrl "Andy's Sidekick 04/11/11"]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. [[Team Coco]]. April 12, 2011. In May 2011 he began conducting backstage interviews with celebrity guests for a [[web series]] called "The Pardo Patrol."[http://teamcoco.com/pardopatrol "The Pardo Patrol"]. TeamCoco.com. Retrieved July 16, 2013. After doing live talk and game shows at such [[Alternative comedy]] venues as the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theater]], Jimmy Pardo began the award-winning podcast ''[[Never Not Funny]]'' at the urging of now-producer Matt Belknap. The show is in its twenty-first season[http://pardcast.com/blog/ "Never Not Funny"]. pardcast.com. Retrieved July 16, 2013. and placed Pardo among the founders of comedian podcasting. Pardo has been called a "pioneer" of podcasting.{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2011/05/jimmy-pardo-is-conans-warm-up-guy-and-podcast-pioneer.html | title=Jimmy Pardo is Conan's warm-up guy -- and podcast pioneer |website=Los Angeles Times |date=May 13, 2011 }} ''Never Not Funny'' primarily features fellow comedians in improvised conversations. Many of his guests have gone on to host their own podcasts, including Doug Benson, Scott Aukerman and Paul Gilmartin. In September 2013, Pardo released a comedy album entitled ''Sprezzatura''.{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/kyle-dowling/comedian-jimmy-pardo-disc_b_3990624.html |title=Comedian Jimmy Pardo Wins With "Sprezzatura" |website=The Huffington Post |date=January 23, 2013 |first=Kyle |last=Dowling}} ==Personal life== Pardo is married to comedy writer Danielle Koenig,{{IMDb name |id=nm0462814 |name=Danielle Koenig}} daughter of actor [[Walter Koenig]]. They have one son.http://www.earwolf.com/episode/jimmy-and-oliver-pardo-father-son-hamilheads/ ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name | id = 1107058}} *[http://www.jimmypardo.com Jimmy Pardo's Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080626080212/http://www.sfstandup.com/blog/2008/06/10/jimmy-pardo-interview/ Interview from June 2008] *[http://www.pardcast.com/ Jimmy Pardo's "Never Not Funny" Podcast] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091127105535/http://laist.com/2009/11/24/meet_jimmy_pardo.php Meet Jimmy Pardo: Never Not Having Fun] on [[LAist]] {{Never Not Funny}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pardo, Jimmy}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:American Academy of Dramatic Arts alumni]] [[Category:American game show hosts]] [[Category:American podcasters]] [[Category:American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male actors from Chicago]] [[Category:People from Cook County, Illinois]] [[Category:Comedians from Illinois]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:People from Oak Forest, Illinois]] [[Category:20th-century American comedians]] [[Category:21st-century American comedians]]
